user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_CopyToReturnValue:
```c
void UT_Stub_CopyToReturnValue(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const void *BufferPtr, size_t BufferSize)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);
    if (StubPtr != NULL)
    {
        /* If the size does not match, there is a bug */
        if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize != BufferSize)
        {
            UtAssert_Abort("Size mismatch in setting return value");
        }
        else
        {
            memcpy(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, BufferPtr, BufferSize);
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position = BufferSize;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_CopyToReturnValue:
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the presented code fragment. Everything in the function is standard C: the function definition, pointer and size_t usage, NULL checks, structure member access, calls to UtAssert_Abort and memcpy, and simple assignments and comparisons are all valid standard C constructs. The provided typedef line (typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t) does introduce an unfamiliar identifier cpuaddr, but that alone is not necessarily a language extension — it is most likely a platform-specific typedef defined elsewhere. Because the rule requires reporting only explicit compiler language extensions (e.g., GCC/Clang __attribute__, __builtin_..., typeof, statement-expressions, nested functions, asm, Microsoft __declspec, etc.), and none of those or any other documented compiler-specific keywords or constructs appear in the supplied code, there are no fragments to flag for investigation.
